title: Prayer for Victory
shortSummary: Psalm 60 is a heartfelt lament and prayer of King David during a time of military defeat and national distress. It expresses deep trust in God's power to restore and deliver His people despite present hardships, emphasizing reliance on divine strength over human aid.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David, during conflicts with Aram-Naharaim, Aram-Zobah, and Edom

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The author of the psalm and king of Israel, who leads the people in seeking God's help during military struggles.

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: David’s military commander who led the victorious campaign against Edom, as referenced in the psalm.

definitions.definition: A term of uncertain meaning, often understood as a type of poetic inscription or a golden poem, indicating the psalm’s special significance.
A flag or standard used in battle to rally and encourage those who fear God, symbolizing divine protection and truth.
A metaphor for overwhelming distress or suffering that God’s people are made to endure.
A basin used for washing feet or hands; here used figuratively to express subjugation or humiliation of Moab.

outline.heading: David’s Lament and Plea for Restoration
outline.description: David opens by acknowledging God’s displeasure and the resulting national calamity, pleading for God to turn back and heal the broken land and people.

outline.heading: God’s Banner and Promise of Deliverance
outline.description: David declares that God has given a banner to those who fear Him as a sign of truth and protection, and he prays for salvation through God’s mighty hand.

outline.heading: God’s Sovereign Claim over the Land
outline.description: God speaks of His authority over the territories of Israel and surrounding nations, affirming His control and the eventual triumph of His people.

outline.heading: David’s Request for Divine Guidance and Help
outline.description: David asks God to lead him into battle and provide help, recognizing that human aid is futile and that victory depends solely on God’s power.

application: Trust God’s sovereignty even in times of defeat and discouragement, knowing He controls all circumstances.
Approach God in honest lament and prayer, bringing your struggles before Him with faith for restoration.
Rely on God’s strength rather than human resources when facing spiritual or physical battles.
Take courage in God’s promises and His provision of a ‘banner’ to rally and protect His people.

keyVerses.text: O God, thou hast cast us off, thou hast scattered us, thou hast been displeased; O turn thyself to us again.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the psalmist’s honest cry for God’s mercy amid judgment and distress.

keyVerses.text: Thou hast given a banner to them that fear thee, that it may be displayed because of the truth. Selah.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God’s provision of protection and encouragement for His faithful followers.

keyVerses.text: Give us help from trouble: for vain is the help of man.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the futility of relying on human strength apart from God’s intervention.

keyVerses.text: Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the victorious power of God working through His people.
